Fig. 1 (a) Scheme for the synthesis route of untreated and mechanochemistry-assisted Ni-supported Beta catalysts with 5 wt% Ni loading. (b, c) Propylene consumption rate and conversion as a function of time on stream and (d, e) C6 selectivity as a function of propylene conversion on Ni-based Beta catalysts prepared using various mechanochemical methods. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns of pristine Beta and Ni-based Beta with different ball-milling times. (b) The changes in structural parameters and elementary composition with different ball-milling times based on the data in Table S2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 STEM and HRTEM images of (a, b) Ni/Beta, (c, d) Ni/Beta-BM10h, and (e, f) Ni/Beta-DBM. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 FT-IR spectra of Ni-based samples using pyridine as the probe molecule in the hydroxyl region. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 for Ni-based Beta catalysts with different pretreatments. (b) Ni K-edge XANES and (c) k 2-weighted Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra of Ni-based Beta catalysts with different ball-milling treatments and Ni foil standard. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) UV-Vis-NIR DR spectra of Beta, Ni/Beta, and Ni/Beta-BMxh catalysts. (b) H2-TPR profiles of Ni-based Beta catalysts with different pretreatments. (c) Propylene consumption rate as a function of the proportion of different reduction peaks. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) Effect of space time on the conversion of propylene and the selectivity of oligomeric products. (b-d) Dimer distribution as a function of the conversion of propylene over Ni/Beta-BM10h catalyst. Conditions: T = 70 °C, P = 2.5 MPa, WHSV = 3.6 − 18.0 gC3/gcat.·h−1. Clark Data curation b Bowen Du Formal analysis a Changhai Liang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals and Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals and Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals and Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China b Paul Scherrer Institut, Forschungstrasse 111, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland Paul Scherrer Institut Forschungstrasse 111 Villigen PSI 5232 Switzerland Paul Scherrer Institut, Forschungstrasse 111, 5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland ⁎ Corresponding author. Propylene oligomerization over nickel-based catalysts has been developed as an attractive route to produce high-value fine chemicals and clean fuels. In this work, the coordination environment of nickel species on high-loading Ni/Beta catalysts is successfully regulated by mechanochemistry, exhibiting a remarkable promotion in activity for propylene dimerization. The optimized ball-milled catalyst with rich four-coordinated nickel species exhibits a higher initial rate of 139.6 molC3=/(molNi·h) than the conventional impregnated catalyst (57.5 molC3=/(molNi·h)). Mechanochemistry induces a strong metal-support interaction by transforming more Ni species into the zeolite channel to generate four-coordinated Ni cations, boosting the adsorption and activation of propylene. Additionally, in-situ Fourier Transform Infrared experiments reveal that propylene dimerization complies with the Cossee-Arlman mechanism via the initial π-adsorption of propylene instead of σ-adsorption. The steric hindrance of the Ni-alkyl intermediate is critical for product selectivity, driving the dimer distribution away from thermodynamic equilibrium and resulting in preferential 1,2-insertion and 2,2-insertion products. Graphical Abstract With the mechanochemical assistance, the chemical environment of a large amount of Ni species in Ni/Beta was regulated from six-coordinated state to a four-coordinated state coordinated to zeolite framework oxygen atoms, which boosts the dimerization of propylene. ga1 Keywords Propylene dimerization Mechanochemistry Ni/Beta Strong metal-support interaction Cossee-Arlman mechanism Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hexenes, including linear, mono-branched, and di-branched isomers, are preferred in the dimerization of propylene, as they are important intermediates in the synthesis of high-value products, such as fragrances, agrochemicals, gasoline additives and as a co-monomer for thermoplastic resin [1–4]. Ni-containing samples, which benefit from the “nickel effect” presented by Ziegler, exhibit outstanding performance for selective dimerization instead of polymerization [1,4]. Since Dimersol operated as the first industrial implementation in the 1970 s, a few Ni-based homogeneous catalytic systems have been applied industrially for the production of dimeric products [1]. However, its development is restricted to its drawbacks of high operating costs resulting from catalyst recycling, as well as the environmental pollution with the use of toxic solvents and organic ligands. Presently, in parallel to the homogeneous mode, the heterogeneous nickel-based olefin oligomerization catalytic systems have also been extensively studied. However, the biggest challenge is its selectivity due to the complexity of the distribution profile of longer olefins, the linearity, and the position of the double bond. It is extremely desirable but challenging to investigate the relationship between the structure and the reactivity/selectivity and identify and design the Ni active sites and mechanisms to choose the most appropriate nickel environment [1]. Over the years, the identification of catalytically active Ni sites has remained elusive, restricting the understanding and development of reaction mechanisms. NiO nanoparticles have been previously considered as active centers to catalyze the oligomerization of light olefins [5,6]. Recent studies, however, have pointed out that the NiO aggregation is unhelpful and sometimes even harmful to the reactivity [7–10]. Instead, the isolated Ni site is better considered as the active center for the reaction. Thus, several strategies have been attempted, especially to choose appropriate solid supports to disperse Ni species, such as amorphous aluminosilicate [11–14], zeolites [8,15–17], mesostructured materials [18–20], and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [21–23], making use of their anchorable sites. Typically, aluminosilicates are applied as a matrix with abundant ion-exchanged sites to strongly anchor metal cations in isolation. However, the number of strongly anchorable sites is finite, and once these sites are saturated the weakly interacting nickel species will be prone to aggregate to NiO species. Taking Ni/Beta as an example, it has been reported that its maximum Ni-exchanged content is 1.4 – 2.5 wt% [7,10]. It is effective to enhance the metal-support interaction to provide more isolated Ni species. However, the diversity of Ni species will inevitably cause a low catalyst efficiency since not all isolated Ni sites are highly reactive [11,14,22,24]. Importantly, the reactivity of isolated Ni species is highly associated with their coordination environment. Depending strongly on the solid support, low-coordinated Ni2+ cations contribute to the reaction by varying the local structure of Ni species. Three-coordinated Ni2+ cations in MCM-41 and LTA and four-coordinated Ni2+ cations in Beta are speculated to be active sites, respectively [8,25,26]. It is difficult to control the unicity of Ni species, especially at a high metal loading. Therefore, regulating the coordination environment is meaningful and useful to enhance the reactivity. Mechanochemical assistance is known as an effective approach to strengthen the metal-support interaction and fabricate ultrasmall metal nanoparticles, especially for catalysts with a high metal loading [27–30]. It has been found that welding, particle deformation, and fracture are generated by the process of repeated ball-powder collisions [31]. The mechanical energy generated under ball-milling conditions can unexpectedly facilitate a rearrangement of metal cations, resulting in the regulation of the coordination environment of metal species and the creation of new catalytically active sites [32,33], which is beneficial to the catalytic performance of supported catalysts in olefin oligomerization. It has been confirmed by Lee et al. that the grinding treatment would induce an additional Ni species and result in a higher reactivity of ethylene dimerization than the impregnated sample when the Ni loading was below 2.0 wt% [24]. However, for the high Ni-content catalyst, it has been reported that the participation of organic ligands can effectively strengthen the metal-support interaction and anchor the metal species in dispersion [34,35]. But the insurmountable induction of heteroatoms such as nitrogen in residual ligands might influence the coordination environment of nickel species and thus inhibit the catalytic activity. The mechanochemical protocol is also expected to facilitate the oligomerization reaction of olefins by regulating the local structure of catalytically active Ni sites. In this study, we report a simple and versatile ball-milling method which is applied to prepare highly dispersed Ni-based Beta zeolites (Ni/Beta-BMxh) with high metal loading. Importantly, the geometrical configuration and the location of Ni species could be regulated by mechanochemistry, which rendered it an efficient catalyst for the dimerization of propylene to C6 olefins. Moreover, we attempted to investigate the chemical state, the local structure of catalytically active Ni sites, and the formation mechanism of the mechanochemistry-induced highly dispersed Ni species with strong metal-support interactions. Furthermore, the adsorption behavior and the reaction mechanistic understanding for the dimerization of propylene over Ni-based catalysts have been proposed. The experimental results can provide rational and useful guidance for designing Ni-based oligomerization catalysts of light olefins while the exploration of active sites is conducive to deepening the comprehension of the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of Ni/Beta catalyst In a typical synthesis of wet-impregnated materials, the commercially available H-type Beta (SiO2/Al2O3 = 25, Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd.) was mixed and stirred within an appropriate amount of the nickel solution (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O) to reach a theoretical 5 wt% nickel loading. After impregnation, the sample was dried at 110 °C overnight and labeled as Ni(NO3)2/Beta. Subsequently, the sample was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in an O2/Ar atmosphere, denoted as Ni/Beta. 2.1.2 Preparation of Ni/Beta-BMxh catalysts In the synthesis of ball-milled samples, the as-impregnated Ni(NO3)2/Beta was ground by using a QM-3SP04 planetary ball mill with a 50 mL agate grinding jar and some agate grinding balls with various sizes. Ball-milling was conducted for different times, namely 2, 10, and 18 h, at 200 rpm, which were denoted as Ni(NO3)2/Beta-BMxh (x = 2, 10, or 18, BM = ball-milled). After calcination at 550 °C for 4 h, the samples were denoted as Ni/Beta-BMxh. 2.1.3 Preparation of Ni/Beta-BMyrpm catalysts The effect of milling energy was also investigated by changing the milling speed. Similar with the synthesis of Ni/Beta-BMxh, the Ni/Beta-BMyrpm catalysts were prepared by altering the speeds at 300 and 400 rpm and subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 4 h, which were denoted as Ni/Beta-BMyrpm catalysts (y = 300 and 400). 2.1.4 Preparation of Ni/Beta-DBM catalyst For comparison, the directly ball-milled catalyst was prepared without the wet impregnation step, by directly grinding H-Beta powder together with nickel precursor (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O) to reach a nominal nickel loading of 5 wt%, following the same milling procedure as above. After ball-milling for 10 h, the obtained material was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h, denoted as Ni/Beta-DBM (DBM = directly ball-milled). 2.1.5 Preparation of Ni/BM_Beta catalyst For comparison, Ni supported on ball-milled H-Beta (denoted as Ni/BM_Beta) was also prepared. H-Beta zeolite was ball-milled for 10 h in the absence of the nickel precursor before the impregnation with a Ni(NO3)2 solution. The impregnated sample was then dried in an oven overnight at 110 °C, after which the catalyst was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. 2.1.6 Preparation of NiO/Beta-BM catalyst NiO/Beta-BM was prepared by ball-milling the mixture of H-Beta and NiO powder for 10 h. Subsequently, the milled sample was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray fluorescence (XRF) was performed on a Bruker AXS S8 TIGER analytical instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out by a Rigaku SmartLab-9 kW diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation. N2 adsorption isotherms were collected by a Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ instrument at − 196 °C. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was outgassed under vacuum at 300 °C. The specific surface area of the catalyst was calculated using the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method, while the total pore volume was estimated at a relative pressure of 0.99. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images were acquired by a JEOL JEM-F200 microscopy. In addition, the morphologies of the samples were obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) over a Hitachi UHR FE-SEM SU8220 microscopy. Attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 infrared spectrometer with 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted in an argon stream from 30° to 800°C by a Discovery SDT 650 from TA Instruments. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out by an EscaLab-250Xi+ spectrometer using an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X-ray beam. The binding energies were calibrated using C1s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference. UV–visible-near infrared diffuse reflectance (UV-Vis-NIR DR) absorption spectra were obtained by a PerkinElmer Lambda 1050 + spectrophotometer. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II-2920 chemisorption apparatus. For each experiment, approximately 50 mg of catalyst was loaded in a U-tube and calcined at 300 °C under an argon atmosphere. After being cooled to 50 °C, a 10% H2/Ar gaseous mixture was imported into the catalyst cell. The catalyst was then heated with a constant rise rate from 50° to 800 °C to detect the reduction behavior. In-situ FT-IR spectra of chemisorbed pyridine and propylene were collected in a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 infrared spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector cooled with liquid N2. For the pyridine adsorption experiment, the samples (∼20 mg) were prepared as self-supporting wafers and outgassed under vacuum at 400 °C in situ for 1 h. After being cooled to 50 °C, the background spectrum was collected and subsequently pyridine was introduced into the system until saturated adsorption. The system was then evacuated for 0.5 h at 150 °C. Scans were recorded with 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. For the propylene adsorption experiment, a self-supporting wafer (∼20 mg) was installed and outgassed under vacuum at 500 °C for 1 h. After being cooled to 25 °C, the time-resolved propylene adsorption experiment was performed at a constant pressure of 2 mbar. Spectra were recorded after different adsorption times with 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements at the Ni K-edge (8333.0 eV), including X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), were performed at the SuperXAS beamline of the Swiss Light Source, Paul Scherrer Institute, Switzerland. During the measurement, the storage ring current was at 400 mA. The beamline is equipped with a 2.9 T superbend source with a Si coating collimating mirror at 2.9 mrad. The liquid nitrogen cooled Si (111) channel cut monochromator is set in QEXAFS mode. The area of the beam illumination on the sample is 1 mm × 0.2 mm (hxv) which is focused by the Rh-coated mirror. The ion chamber is filled with pure nitrogen gas under the pressure at 1 bar. In QEXAFS mode [36,37], the data were collected for 300 s while the metal Ni foil calibration was being performed simultaneously. To process the spectral data, the ProQEXAFS package was used for calibration [38], interpolation, normalization, and averaging, and the Demeter program [39] was used for Fourier analysis. The data ranges used in the fit are 3.0 ≤ k ≤ 12.5 Å−1 and 1.2 ≤ R ≤ 3.0 Å. The number of variable parameters is 7, out of a total of 10.5 independent data points. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance of the synthesized materials for propylene dimerization was measured using a fixed-bed microreactor (i.d. = 8 mm). Typically, 500 mg of catalyst was diluted with quartz sand to 4.0 mL and subsequently loaded into the central isothermal zone of the tube reactor. Catalysts were pretreated under an Ar flow at 300 °C for 2 h to free from moisture and then the system was cooled to the desired reaction temperature. After the reactor was pressurized to the target pressure using argon, a high-pressure liquid mixture of propylene and propane (inert propane as the internal standard and mpropylene / mpropane = 9:1) was pumped into the reactor. After the reaction, the outflow was separated in a gas-liquid separator and the gas was recorded by an online chromatograph (GC7820) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The liquid products were collected from a cold trap and analyzed by an Agilent chromatograph (GC7890A) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a PONA capillary column. The propylene conversion (X), selectivity ( Si ) for each product (i), weight hourly space velocity (WHSV), and propylene consumption rate (r p ) were calculated as follows: (1) X = n 0 − n t n 0 × 100 % (2) S i = n i ∑ n i × 100 % (3) WHSV = F W (4) r p = F × X 42 × n Ni where n 0 and n t are the moles of propylene in the feed and product, respectively. n i represents the moles of i product molecule and Σn i represents the total moles of products. In addition, F denotes the weight flow rate of propylene, W denotes the catalyst weight, and n Ni denotes the mole of Ni in the catalyst. In addition, the mass diffusion transport limitation was checked by the Mears criterion and Weisz-Prater criterion, (5) C M = − r ( obs ) × ρ b × R × n k c × C b < 0.15 (6) C WP = − r A ρ c R 2 C As D e < 1 The detailed calculations of the Mears criterion and Weisz-Prater criterion are described in the Supplementary Material, and the calculated values of CM and CWP in this case are 1.39 × 10−6 and 8.22 × 10−6, respectively, suggesting that the mass transfer limitation can be ignored in the activity measurement. The turnover frequency (TOF) can be applied using the average particle sizes by TEM as reported previously [40,41]. The TOF value of the sample is calculated based on statistical results of TEM images by the following equation: (7) TOF h − 1 = N propylene N Ni · D m · t where N propylene denotes the transferred number of propylene molecules. The propylene conversion was kept low to avoid the diffusion effect, which was controlled by lowering the reaction time and catalyst dosage; t is the reaction time in hours; N Ni is the total number of Ni atoms in the catalyst; and D m is the surface dispersion degree of Ni, which can be calculated by the equation between the particle area (S NP) and weight (m NP) of one NiO nanoparticle (NP), as well as the sectional area of one NiO nanoparticle (S NiO) (8) D m = S NP / S NiO · M ̅ N iO m NP · N A where M ̅ NiO is the molar mass of NiO (74.7 g/mol) and N A is the Avogadro constant. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of the Ni/Beta catalytic system on propylene dimerization A series of Ni/Beta-BMxh materials (x = 2, 10, and 18) with different ball-milling times were prepared via wet-impregnation followed by ball-milling and calcination in O2/Ar ( Fig. 1a). The catalytic activities for propylene dimerization over the Ni/Beta-BMxh series were evaluated under the conditions of T = 70 °C, P = 2.5 MPa and WHSV = 7.2 gC3/gcat.·h−1, as shown in Fig. 1b-e. For comparison, the activities were also examined for other ball-milled Ni-based catalysts prepared using various mechanochemical methods (Ni/Beta, Ni/Beta-DBM, and Ni/BM_Beta, for details, see Table S1). The uncalcined Ni(NO3)2/Beta-BM10h catalyst was inactive due to the remaining H2O and NO3 - ligands. Additionally, the control experiment using the metal-free Beta support exhibited a relatively low activity and suffered a severe deactivation, whereas the reactivity of the calcined Ni-based samples was greatly improved. It suggests that Ni sites are the major active centers and provide the dominant dimerization activity. Moreover, it is clear that the activity of Ni-based catalysts is highly sensitive to the ball-milling processing, especially the ball-milling time (Fig. 1b). The results indicated that the assistance of the mechanochemical technique could indeed contribute to improving the performance of the catalysts. Therein, the Ni/Beta-BM10h catalyst showed the best performance towards propylene dimerization with an initial reaction rate of 139.6 molC3/(molNi·h). It should be mentioned that a follow-up prolongation of ball-milling time was expected to further promote the improvement of catalytic activity. Unexpectedly, it was found that an excessive prolongation to 18 h led to a damage to the activity, with the reaction rate decreasing to 107.5 molC3/(molNi·h). For comparison, we further investigated the dimerization performance of Ni-based catalysts under different pretreatment procedures, which is illustrated in Fig. 1c. Interestingly, except NiO/Beta-BM, all the mechanochemistry-assisted catalysts facilitated the conversion of propylene. NiO/Beta-BM exhibited a similar behavior with metal-free Beta zeolite. The resultant C3H6 consumption rates on Ni/BM_Beta and Ni/Beta-DBM were 70.6 and 78.1 molC3/(molNi·h), respectively. However, the catalytic activities of both the Ni-based catalysts prepared by directly ball-milling (Ni/Beta-DBM) and impregnation on the pre-milled Beta (Ni/BM_Beta) were lower than that of Ni/Beta-BM10h. The activity difference indicated that the mechanochemical assistance could synergistically work on both the support and the active metal. Particularly, the pre-impregnation was confirmed to be an indispensable procedure, which might be due to the pre-dispersion of Ni precursor, leading to a significant activity gap between Ni/Beta-DBM and Ni/Beta-BM10h. The outstanding performance of the as-prepared sample suggested that the mechanochemical assistance was an effective tool, especially for the high-loading catalyst, and could result in unique structural characteristics that were beneficial to the dimerization activity. In addition, the selectivity of dimers as a key parameter was also investigated. The dimer selectivity is plotted against propylene conversion in Figs. 1d and 1e. The pristine Beta as the blank experiment showed an extremely lower C6 selectivity via a distinctive reaction pathway [10], while Ni-containing samples exhibited a pronounced improvement in C6 selectivity. The improvement was attributed to the Ni species generating a different reaction mechanism that promoted the desorption of dimeric products and prevented propylene from excessively oligomerizing to larger oligomers [8,17]. It was expected that the C6 selectivity would decrease with increasing propylene conversion since the high activity of Ni active species would result in an excessive oligomerization. However, interestingly, all the ball-milled series with a higher catalytic activity concurrently presented a higher selectivity to dimers (75.4%) than the untreated Ni/Beta (68.7%). The improvement might be associated with the mechanochemical effect on the support structure, thus facilitating the desorption of dimers. As a result, Ni/Beta-BM10h exhibited an outstanding C6 yield of 52.3% which was higher than the Ni/Beta as well as all the other ball-milled samples under the same reaction conditions. Notably, C3n products with the Schulz-Flory type distribution were observed while few non-C3n products were detected. The absence of a cracking reaction indicated that the acid sites had negligible activity for oligomerization under mild reaction conditions. This is because the formation of larger oligomers on acid sites needs a high temperature [10]. It is confirmed that Ni/Beta-BM10h synthesized by wet-impregnation and subsequent ball-milling for 10 h is an excellent catalyst with a higher catalyst efficiency than those previously reported in the literature, along with outstanding C6 selectivity ( Table 1). Furthermore, as previously reported [31], the milling speed could bring a higher milling energy and result in a stronger interaction, which might influence the catalytic performance. The effect of milling speed was investigated by comparing Ni/Beta-BM10h (200 rpm) with the catalysts synthesized at higher milling speeds (300 rpm and 400 rpm). As shown in Fig. S1, the catalytic activity of the catalyst was improved significantly with the increase in the milling speed. That might be due to a stronger metal-support interaction resulted from a higher milling energy, as observed from XRD and TPR results (Fig. S2). Therefore, the mechanochemical assistance on the impregnated sample is an effective method for improving the catalytic performance including the reactivity and selectivity to dimers. The improvement might be due to the enhancement of the metal-support interaction and the regulation of the chemical states of Ni catalytic sites. 3.2 Physical properties of catalysts To illustrate the reasons for the significantly improved catalytic performance of Ni/Beta-BM10h, the mechanochemical effects on the structural properties and the chemical states of Ni-based catalysts were investigated. The effect of milling time on the physical properties of various ball-milled catalysts is presented in Fig. 2, and the detailed data are summarized in Table S2. As expected, the Ni loading and Si/Al ratio in the Ni-containing samples determined by XRF were approximately 5 wt% and 12.0, respectively, which were seldom influenced by the various mechanochemical degrees. As intended, all the samples had similar N2 adsorption isotherms with the shape of type I as shown in Fig. S3, exhibiting a structural characteristic of zeolite with almost the same nanocrystal size (Fig. S4). It is noted that the untreated Ni/Beta catalyst displayed severely lower values for the BET surface area (248 m2/g) and total pore volume (0.406 cm3/g) than those of the pristine Beta sample (612 m2/g, 0.847 cm3/g). The decreases in structural parameters could not be simply ascribed to the damage of the zeolite structure. As will be displayed below in the XRD results, the crystallinity of the Ni/Beta sample remained almost unchanged compared with that of the parent Beta material. Therefore, this is likely due to a partial pore blockage resulted from the formation of NiO crystallites. On the contrary, an evident increase in both the specific surface area and the total pore volume was noticed for the ball-milled series (Table S2, Entry 3–7) relative to the untreated Ni/Beta. The increases in structural parameters under the mechanochemical treatment were attributed to a high dispersion of the NiO nanoparticles which were observed below by XRD in the Ni-based samples. Additionally, the BET area reached a maximum (499 m2/g) with the sample ball-milling for 10 h and decreased with an accumulated ball-milled time, possibly due to the partial crystallinity damage. The decrease in the catalytic activity might be ascribed to the partial framework destruction, as evidenced by the structural properties. The intrinsic catalytic activity would very likely increase further with milling time. However, this is overcompensated by a severe loss in surface area to 379 m2/g with extended ball milling after 18 h. The severe loss in BET surface area might take the main responsibility for Ni-based Beta catalysts, similarly with the previous studies [43,44]. The XRD patterns for the calcined Ni/Beta catalyst and the ball-milled series are shown in Fig. 2a. For comparison, the pattern of the pristine Beta material is also involved. Evidenced by comparing the diffraction patterns with that of the parent zeolite, the high crystallinity assigned to the *BEA structure in the Ni-based samples was almost reserved. As seen in the indexing patterns, diffraction peaks at ca. 37.3° and 43.4° attributed to the NiO crystallites were distinct in the untreated Ni/Beta catalyst [45,46]. In contrast, the ball-milled catalysts prepared by various mechanochemical treatments only displayed the peaks associated with the *BEA crystal structure, which further verified the high dispersion of Ni species. Obviously, such large NiO nanoparticles came to a smaller average size after the ball-milling procedure and might consequently conduce to significantly larger specific surface area and total pore volume. However, it should be noticed that the analysis might be misdirected by the close peak positions for Beta zeolite and NiO nanocrystal. Thus, the electron microscopy was further applied to identify the nanoparticle size for clarification. As intended, the statistical average size of the NiO crystallites is 11.8 ± 3.1 nm for the untreated Ni/Beta catalyst and decreases to 9.2 ± 2.1 nm and 2.8 ± 0.4 nm for Ni/Beta-DBM and Ni/Beta-BM10h, respectively ( Figs. 3a – 3f). Notably, obvious X-ray diffraction peaks ascribed to NiO nanoparticles have been previously reported for the Ni/Beta catalyst with only 3.8 wt% Ni loading [7], suggesting that a stronger metal-support interaction by the mechanochemical assistance could indeed prevent the agglomeration of nickel species. Therefore, a preparatory wet-impregnation pretreatment might provide a pre-dispersion of Ni species and the subsequent ball-milling developed an enhanced anchoring effect, thus promoting the separation of Ni species and protecting the NiO nanoparticles to retain a smaller average size. As shown in Table S3, the turnover frequency via Ni/Beta-BM10h is calculated to be 1002 h−1, significantly higher than that of the impregnated Ni/Beta catalyst (766 h−1). To inquire about the formation mechanism of the mechanochemistry-induced high-dispersed structure of Ni species, the uncalcined Ni(NO3)2/Beta precursors with various milling times were investigated by XRD, ATR-FTIR, and TG analysis to monitor the structural evolution. No X-ray diffraction peaks associated with Ni(NO3)2 were detected in any of the samples (Fig. S5), indicating that Ni(NO3)2 could be well dispersed on the surface of the support during the impregnating process. The structure of the Ni(NO3)2/Beta-BMxh precursors was further investigated by ATR-FTIR (Fig. S6). The absorption band at 1221 cm−1 was ascribed to Si-O-Si vibrations in the five-member ring building, which decreased in intensity during the milling process, suggesting partial silicon extraction [47]. In addition, the band at 1052 cm−1 representing the Si–O–T (T = Si or Al) asymmetric stretching vibration redshifted monotonously with an accumulative ball-milling time, which might be due to the increasing surface aluminum content in the zeolite structure [34,48,49]. As shown in Fig. S6, the Si–O–T asymmetric stretching vibration that appeared at 1052 cm−1 for the untreated sample redshifted gradually to 1038 cm−1 for Ni(NO3)2/Beta-BM18h, respectively, showing that the wavenumber decreased with an increase in the ball-milling time. These observations were ascribed to the fact that an increasing amount of framework aluminum atoms was exposed on the zeolite surface. The result was in line with the decreasing surface Si/Al ratio measured by XPS while the overall element composition was unchanged (Fig. 2b and Table S2). Furthermore, TG analysis (Fig. S7) revealed that the mechanochemical treatment resulted in some surface reactions during the milling processing instead of simple mechanical mixing of Ni species and the support. The strong metal-support interaction was induced by the changed structure of the nickel precursor, as evidenced by the gradually rising decomposition temperature of the third decomposition event (basic nitrate intermediate → NiO) [50]. Undoubtedly, the catalytic performance of Ni/Beta samples is closely associated with the mechanochemical treatment. The pronounced improvement in the reaction performance is attributed to the enhanced interaction between the Ni species and support, producing more potential active sites to facilitate the conversion of propylene. The highly dispersed NiO species were detected after the mechanochemical processing. However, NiO nanoparticles were previously reported to be the reaction spectators [7–10]. While the surface NiO nanoparticles were dispersed, a larger amount of coordinatively unsaturated Ni sites were exposed [51]. Therefore, mechanochemical assistance can regulate the chemical states of Ni species that contribute to the dimerization of propylene. Therefore, it is important to investigate the chemical states of Ni species after the mechanochemical processing. 3.3 Identification of the state of the catalytically active Ni species 3.3.1 Elucidation of surface hydroxyl species Impregnation followed by ball-milling has been seen as an attractive method to synthesize a highly reactive catalyst. It is expected that the situation of Ni species is a critical factor influencing catalytic behavior [52]. Thus, the absorption bands were explored by the FT-IR technique to elucidate the surface hydroxyl species by using pyridine as a probe molecule [53,54]. After pyridine adsorption on Beta followed by evacuation at 150 °C, all the samples exhibited four negative absorption bands appeared at ∼3745, ∼3733, ∼3663, and ∼3606 cm−1 in the O-H stretching region, while Beta also showed an additional weak band at 3780 cm−1 ( Fig. 4). The absorption bands that appeared at 3780 and 3663 cm−1 were ascribed to the extra-framework AlO-H groups [51,55]. In addition, three other characteristic bands located at ∼3745, ∼3733, and ∼3606 cm−1 were respectively attributed to isolated external SiO-H groups, internal SiO-H groups, and bridging hydroxyls Si-O(H)-Al [25,56]. The introduction of nickel ions into Beta led to the disappearance of the band at 3780 cm−1, suggesting that nickel ions preferentially interact with the corresponding Al-related hydroxyl groups of Beta [55]. The silanol groups had a weak acidic character; therefore, it was expected that nickel would exchange these sites harder than the hydroxyl groups connected to the framework aluminum, which had a more acidic character [10]. However, it is noted that a higher milling degree led to a significant weakness in the adsorption bands ascribed to internal SiO-H groups (3733 cm−1). More Ni species should be associated with Si-related hydroxyl groups. As a result, the mechanochemical approach was confirmed to enhance the interaction between Ni species and the support by providing higher energy to assist Ni species to exchange with the weak acidic silanol groups. Combined with the surface element composition obtained by XPS (Fig. 2b) and the band shift in ATR-FTIR (Fig. S6), a segment of surface Si species was extracted and thus an increasing amount of internal hydroxyl species was exposed to the surface of catalysts during the ball-milling process. The mechanochemical treatment resulted in a larger chance for Ni species to interact with the hydroxyl species, stabilizing the Ni species in a high dispersion. 3.3.2 Exploration of coordination environment and local structure of Ni species Furthermore, considering the critical role of the nickel state in the dimerization of propylene, we investigated the electronic properties and chemical states of nickel species by different characterization analyses. The XPS spectra of the Ni 2p3/2 peaks ( Fig. 5a) showed that all four catalysts exhibited two peaks at approximately 857.2–857.4 eV (peak I) and 853.5–854.4 eV (peak II) in addition to the satellite peak. It suggests that no Ni0 species existed in the catalysts and the oxidation state of the Ni species remained at + 2 [45,46]. The peak II with lower binding energy corresponded to the outer-surface NiO nanoparticles in a weak interaction with the Beta support, accounting for a minor proportion. Instead, the majority was assigned to the nickel species interacting strongly with the surface group of the support [34,57]. A stronger metal-support interaction during the mechanochemical processing was evidenced by a significantly increased concentration of the peak I (∼90%) for the ball-milling derived samples, in contrast to the reference catalyst prepared by the conventional wet impregnation (Ni/Beta, 71%). The strong interaction was also confirmed by the negative shift in peak II with a high ball-milled degree, attributed to electron transfer from the support to Ni2+ species. An accordant result was obtained by X-ray absorption spectroscopy. Fig. 5b shows the Ni K-edge XANES region for the Ni-based Beta samples along with Ni foil as the reference. Also, the edge energies (Table S4) of the Ni-based samples apparently indicated that the oxidation state of Ni was + 2 in the as-prepared samples, and the electron transfer of Ni2+ cations and support was enhanced [14,17,58]. A slight shift to lower energy for the pre-edge energy was observed, which was ascribed to the transformation of Ni2+ cations in (six-coordinated) Oh symmetry to (four-coordinated) tetrahedral symmetry [21,59], indicating a decreasing average coordination number. The coordination environment of Ni2+ cations was assessed from the EXAFS region (Fig. S8–S9). Fig. 5c shows the Fourier-transforms of Ni-based Beta catalysts with different ball-milling treatments at the Ni K-edge and the results are summarized in Table S4. The fitted EXAFS model considered the first shell to represent Ni-O scattering pair and the second shell to represent Ni-Ni corresponding to a NiO structure, and is noted as different from Ni-Ni scatter in Ni foil [24–26]. Upon fitting, the corresponding coordination numbers of the Ni-O shell and the Ni-Ni shell for Ni/Beta-BMxh catalysts were monotonically decreased from 6.0 to 5.2 and from 5.6 to 2.8 with longer milling times, respectively, while Ni/Beta-DBM as the reference sample showed medium Ni-O and Ni-Ni coordination numbers between Ni/Beta and Ni/Beta-BM10h. The decreasing number of Ni-Ni pairs suggested that the ability to resist Ni aggregation was improved by the ball-milling treatment. This result strongly agreed with our STEM observations that NiO nanoparticles were highly dispersed for the Ni/Beta-BM10h catalyst. Additionally, a simultaneously decreasing number of Ni-O pairs confirmed the formation of a larger amount of low-coordinated Ni2+ cations. Combined with the pre-edge energy shift observed in the XANES results, more low-coordinated Ni2+ species were exposed under the fabrication condition. The change of coordination number was possibly because the NiO nanoparticles in a weak interaction was transformed into low-coordinated Ni2+ cations bound to the support, remaining a less proportion of six-coordinated Ni species. Thus, all the Ni-based samples exhibited a Ni-O coordination number in the range of 5–6, which was due to the coexistence of four-coordinated and six-coordinated Ni2+ species. Meanwhile, some four-coordinated tetrahedral Ni2+ cations could also transform to a six-coordinated structure after adsorbing water molecules under the ex-situ conditions [25,26]. Prior to reaction, the water ligand on Ni sites would be desorbed during the calcination pretreatment, which helped Ni sites return to a four-coordinated structure. These four-coordinated Ni2+ cations located in distorted tetrahedral geometries were previously considered to be active centers as observed in ethylene dimerization [21,26]. In this study, therefore, the coordination environment of nickel species accompanied by the local structure was changed during the mechanochemical processing, exposing more active low-coordinated Ni sites and facilitating the dimerization of propylene. Additionally, UV−Vis−NIR DR spectra were collected to determine the symmetry and the coordination of nickel species dispersed on the samples, as shown in Fig. 6a. Metal-free Beta as reference showed an adsorption band at ∼1410 nm assigned to vibrations of surface hydroxyl groups of zeolite [60] in addition to a band located at 278 nm. The untreated sample Ni/Beta exhibited several additional bands centered at ∼380, ∼417, ∼720, and ∼1140 nm, typically attributed to 3A2 g → 3T1 g (P), 3A2 g(F) → 3T1 g (P), 3A2 g(F) → 3T1 g(F) and 3A2 g → 3T2 g(F) absorptions, respectively. They were associated with the d−d transition of Ni species with a hexa-coordinated octahedral structure similar to the characteristics of bulk NiO [25,58,61,62]. Additionally, a weak shoulder band at ∼450 nm could be distinguished, which was associated with d-d electron transitions of tetrahedral (four-coordinated) Ni species with four oxygen neighbors inside the zeolite framework [60]. It was confirmed that a large amount of NiO nanoparticles existed in Ni/Beta consistent with the above results, together with a minority of low-coordinated Ni species. As compared, for the ball-milled samples (Ni/Beta-BM10h and -BM18h), the absorption bands were obviously red-shifted to ∼426, ∼760, and ∼1187 nm, while the band at ∼380 nm disappeared. Therein, the adsorption band at ∼760 nm was attributed to the tetrahedrally coordinated Ni2+ ions similar to the band in NiAl2O4 [61]. The redshift was associated with a weaker crystal field energy and a decreasing d-d energy-level splitting of Ni2+, which was resulted from the decreasing coordination number of nickel cations. It suggested that after the mechanochemical treatment the coordination structure of a large amount of Ni species was transformed to a low-coordinated state, most likely to be the four-coordinated Ni cations according to the Beta structure [26,63]. On the other hand, the decreasing average coordination number can also be evidenced by the blueshift in the UV region from 278 nm for Ni/Beta and Ni/Beta-BM2h to 269 nm for Ni/Beta-BM10h and -BM18h, because the four-coordinated nickel ion had a higher O2- → Ni2+ charge transfer energy. In brief, the coordination environment of Ni species was significantly influenced by the milling pretreatment, inducing a larger amount of Ni species in a low-coordinated state. This was observed to be due to the stronger metal-support interaction, which was derived from the reaction of Ni with the surface hydroxyl species of Beta during the mechanochemical treatment. The situation of Ni species changed, as observed above in FT-IR (Fig. 4), which benefitted from the extra energy from mechanochemistry. The provided energy prompted Ni species to incorporate with those O-H species in weak interactions, which rendered Ni species to exhibit an additional unique coordination environment. The complicated coordination environment of Ni species would undoubtedly influence their catalytic activity, which was significantly affected by the Ni situation. Hence, for designing a highly active catalyst, understanding the situation of Ni species is meaningful. However, hindered by the complexity of zeolite channels, it is challenging to determine. Indirect information about the localization of Ni-species in zeolites was obtained from H2-TPR data, and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. Since the ease of reduction of nickel ions with different coordination environments in Beta zeolites decreased in different degrees, H2-TPR measurements were carried out to distinguish the nature of Ni species in Beta zeolite [64,65]. The reduction peaks were deconvoluted into four peaks at ∼350 °C (peak i), ∼430 °C (peak ii), ∼490 °C (peak iii), and ∼580 °C (peak iv), corresponding to four types of Ni species in various local structures, which were dramatically affected by the mechanochemical processing. The detailed data of the reduction peaks are listed in Table S5. The reduction peak i was typically associated with the reduction of NiO species located on the outer zeolite surface, which was in relatively weak interaction with the support [24,64]. In addition, the higher-temperature reduction peak was attributed to the Ni species strongly interacting with the support, which could be deconvoluted into three peaks (peak ii, peak iii, and peak iv). The ease of reduction of nickel ions was previously reported to be closely related to the coordination effect of Ni species situated in different positions in Ni/USY [64]. However, the structure of Beta zeolite, unlike Y zeolite formed by cavities, consists of a three-dimensional system of channels. Therefore, peak ii, peak iii, and peak iv with different reduction temperatures were possibly due to the different coordination environments of Ni species in the Beta framework channels. As Quindimil et al. reported earlier, peak ii was ascribed to small-size NiO clusters with a strong metal-support interaction [60]. In addition, peak iii and peak iv were attributed to the Ni2+ cation located in the zeolite channel and coordinated to the zeolite framework oxygens, which was hard to reduce. Therein, the latter required the highest reduction temperature corresponding to the isolated Ni species in hexagonal prisms, which was the most difficult to form and occupied the lowest proportion [63]. Except for the three aforementioned hexa-coordinated Ni species, peak iii was attributed to the reduction behavior of Ni2+ in four-coordinated structures to Ni0 species [60]. The cationic Ni site was suggested to be coordinated to four framework oxygens in an elongated six-member ring composed of a twofold connected five-member ring [63]. As expected, the observation of four-coordinated Ni species proved the UV–vis-NIR result. It was also confirmed by the stronger NO adsorption peaks in in-situ FT-IR spectra on Ni/Beta-BM10h than that on Ni/Beta (Fig. S10) [25]. As illustrated in Table S5, all the reduction peaks, except peak iv (5 – 10%), were significantly influenced by the ball-milling treatments. Therein, the highest percentage of peak i was observed on the untreated Ni/Beta (29%) among the catalysts, similar to the XPS result, reconfirming a large amount of NiO nanoparticles interacting weakly with support located outside the Ni/Beta. Ball-milling treatments could significantly improve the interaction between Ni species and Beta support, exhibiting an increased proportion of strongly interacted Ni species and leaving a lower amount of NiO located on the outer zeolite surface. More Ni species turned into the zeolite channel and thus their coordination environments were transformed. Importantly, in line with the EXAFS results, the ball-milled samples created more four-coordinated Ni sites. Especially for Ni/Beta-BM10h, four-coordinated Ni species (reduction peak iii) rose to a dominant position. It has been long considered that NiO nanoparticle supported on aluminosilicate was the active site for the oligomerization of light olefins [5,6]. However, in this study, the activity order is opposite to that of the proportion of extra-framework NiO nanoparticles evidenced by H2-TPR (reduction peak i in Fig. 6c). Additionally, for the Ni/Beta catalysts with lower Ni loadings, it has been confirmed that all the Ni2+ cations are coordinated with the oxygen atoms without NiO species [7]. The highly-dispersed catalysts with lower Ni loadings (0.5% and 2.0%) (Fig. S11) exhibited high and close reaction rates (Fig. S12). As the Ni loading increased to 5.0%, NiO nanoparticles were formed (as shown in TEM) and the reaction rate was decreased, indicating that some of additional Ni species were inactive. Additionally, another catalyst (NiO/Beta-BM) where almost all the Ni species were NiO crystallinity was synthesized by ball-milling NiO and Beta zeolite. The catalyst exhibited a similar propylene conversion with the metal-free Beta support, reconfirming that these NiO species were inactive for the reaction. Interestingly, it is interesting to find that the initial propylene consumption rate exhibited a high correlation with the percentage of reduction peak iii, where the initial activity data were extrapolated to zero proportion, but it seemed irrelevant to the other reduction peaks. It implied that the four-coordinated Ni cations instead of the other (saturated) hexa-coordinated Ni cations were the dominant active species, whether the hexa-coordinated nickel was coordinated to oxygen atoms in the NiO lattice or the zeolite framework oxygen atom. The determination of Ni active species was strongly supported by the previous study on Ni-[Al]Beta by Joshi et al. [26] that four-coordinated Ni2+ cation was a primary catalytically active component for ethylene dimerization. As expected, coordinatively unsaturated Ni sites were easy to adsorb propylene molecules and boost their conversion. With the supplement of this study, a configuration of active Ni site in a four-coordinated structure was reasonably presumed. In comparison to other samples, the Ni/Beta-BM10h catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity, owing to having the highest proportion of four-coordinated Ni species. Undoubtedly, the catalytic performance of the catalysts was boosted by the ball-milling pretreatment, which was associated with a stronger metal-support interaction and the modulated coordination environment of Ni species. This suggests that the assistance of mechanochemical treatment on the as-impregnated sample is verified as a remarkable and effective method to synthesize the catalysts with high performance for propylene dimerization, especially for the catalyst at a high Ni loading. In comparison to Ni/Beta, the ball-milled samples possessed higher Ni dispersion as well as lower extra-framework NiO amounts, exposing more strongly interacted Ni species immersed into the channels of Beta with a lower coordination number. These exposed Ni species over ball-milled samples could potentially endow the catalysts with more dimerization sites, exhibiting a higher dimerization performance. 3.4 Investigation of the dimerization mechanism of propylene over Ni-based Beta catalysts The propylene conversion with varying space time is shown in Fig. 7. Throughout the studied space time range of 3.33–16.67 min, almost all detected products were oligomers. At the shortest space time of 3.33 min, nearly 100% oligomerization product was hexene with a conversion of 9.3% (Fig. 7a). Upon higher space times, a further oligomerization of dimeric products occurred with an increasing propylene conversion, forming C9, C12, and C15 olefins. Therefore, this suggested that dimerization occurred antecedent to trimerization, rather than simultaneously. It is well known that the various hexenes isomers, based on linearity and double-bond position, are important as regards the properties and application of the products [1]. To explore the dimerization mechanism more specifically, 12 dimeric products totally detected in the reaction result were classified into three types, that is, linear, mono-branched, and di-branched hexenes, as shown in Fig. 7b-d. Clearly, the dimer distribution is far away from the thermodynamic equilibrium value. The remarkable difference between the thermodynamic result and the experimental distribution was assumed to be closely associated with the stability of Ni-alkyl intermediate species. For example, 2,3DM2B seems to be the preferential product in a thermodynamic view by the calculation using the HSC Chemistry software (Table S6), but it only occupied a trace proportion (< 5%). In addition, the trans 4-methyl-2-pentene (t4M2P) as the main dimer (∼42%) was almost three times as abundant as its cis-counterparts, due to the steric hindrance of the Ni-alkyl intermediate as reported by de Souza [66]. Likewise, mono-branched dimers correspond to a low steric hindrance and thus occupy a dominant proportion. On the other hand, almost all dimers have been formed at very low conversions, suggesting that isomerization may occur on the Ni sites and the reaction may go through the Cossee-Arlman pathway [66–68]. Therein, the double-bond position in products was also affected by space time. At lower propylene conversions (low space time), terminal olefins occupied a relatively high concentration. High activity favored of the formation of internal olefins. With an increment of conversion, the concentration of internal dimeric olefins was increased. Additionally, a similar result was verified by the comparison with the untreated Ni/Beta sample ( Table 2). Obviously, it can be seen that dimer distribution was influenced by the ball-milling processing at a close C6 selectivity. A larger amount of trans products were obtained on Ni/Beta-BM10h due to the increased steric hindrance of Ni-alkyl intermediates with isolated Ni sites. In addition, the secondary products, such as 2M2P and 2,3DM2B, were easier to form on the highly active Ni/Beta-BM10h. Hence, it suggests that isomerization can also occur on the Ni sites, in agreement with the previous observations [16,66]. As the reaction progressed, these secondary dimers were increased, indicating that the product was hard to desorb from the Ni catalytic species and facile to continue to isomerize to secondary products. This is also supported by the increased proportion of larger oligomers with a longer reaction time as well as the rapid deactivation. The possibility of isomerization activity on Brønsted acid site is neglected because it undergoes deactivation very quickly and requires a very high reaction temperature. Moreover, interestingly, it is worth noting that 4M1P as an α-olefin can be used as the monomer of poly(4-methyl-1-pentene), which is a high-valued thermoplastic resin material as the hollow fiber membrane module of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) [3,69]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the proportion of 4M1P in dimers catalyzed by all the Ni-based and Co-based materials was no more than 6%, except 6.6% for Ni-SrX and 8.3% for Ni-LTA (Table S7) [8,66,70–75]. For Ni-based Beta samples in this study, the selectivity to 4M1P reached 15.6% at most. The outstanding selectivity might profit from the special structure of the *BEA framework. This result may provide a new strategy to modulate the distribution of valuable dimeric products. Furthermore, the mechanism of adsorption and dimerization of propylene on Ni/Beta catalysts was further investigated by time-resolved in-situ FT-IR spectroscopy under a dynamic flow of propylene to ensure the detection of the adsorbed alkyl groups ( Fig. 8). For the pristine Beta sample, the strong adsorption peaks corresponding respectively to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of CH3 groups (2956, 2870 cm−1) and CH2 groups (2929 and 2860 cm−1) were detected [16,25]. In addition, the bands assigned respectively to δ(CH2) at 1468 cm−1 and δ(CH3) at 1381 and 1367 cm−1 developed rapidly with the exposure time in the C3H6 atmosphere [25,76]. This suggested that propylene reacted with Brønsted acid sites of Beta zeolite [10]. A distinctly different phenomenon was observed in the spectra of Ni/Beta and Ni/Beta-BM10h (Fig. 8c-f). However, in the initial period, multiple different IR bands were observed such as 2974, 2948, 2923, 2892, and 2858 cm−1 corresponding to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of C-H groups [16,77,78], indicating that the rapid adsorption of propylene molecule on the surface Ni species of catalysts in preference to the adsorption behavior on Brønsted acid sites. Moreover, the more rapid growth rate in band intensity on the pristine Beta than that on the Ni-based samples was ascribed to the chain growth reactions, facilitating the formation of carbon deposition [10]. The addition of Ni species accelerated the desorption of larger oligomeric products from the surface of the catalyst, which might lead to a relatively high stability as observed in Section 3.1. Furthermore, over Ni/Beta-BM10h for details, a series of additional bands were observed between 1620 and 1650 cm−1 (Fig. 8f), ascribed to the CC in propylene bonded on Ni2+ [16]. Directly after exposure of the sample to a stream of propylene, a band at 1637 cm−1 with a shoulder at 1621 cm−1 and a band at 1601 cm−1 evolved. The former band was ascribed to a typical physisorbed molecule while the latter bands at 1621 cm−1 and 1601 cm−1 were attributed to π-bonded and σ-bonded CC bond of terminal olefin, respectively [79,80]. Additionally, a shoulder band at 1649 cm−1 appeared mostly within the first minute, which was attributed to an adsorbed alkene with an internal CC bond [16]. This band is presumed to be from the dimeric product, indicating that the internal CC bond in the product formed simultaneously with the dimerization of propylene, instead of dimerization followed by isomerization. This is further supported by the observation of a band at 1593 cm−1 ascribed to π-allyl formation [81]. This is consistent with the proposed Cossee-Arlman reaction pathway. For the untreated Ni/Beta as a comparison (Fig. 8d), it is also notable that the adsorption behaviors of CC double bonds are different. CC bond was mainly through π-adsorbed (1621 cm−1) on the isolated Ni2+ species of the ball-milled sample with high metal dispersion, while only the σ-bonded (1599 cm−1) band was detected for the untreated Ni/Beta sample. Therefore, it is reasonable to presume that the isolated Ni sites π-adsorbed with CC bonds is associated with the improved catalytic performance. Combined with the above experimental results, the dimerization of propylene on the Ni-based Beta catalysts is proposed via a Cossee-Arlman reaction pathway ( Fig. 9). The first propylene molecule undergoes π-adsorption on the Ni active species. As propylene is a dissymmetric molecule, its insertion could occur through the primary (Ni → C1) or secondary carbon atom (Ni → C2) of the olefin, forming various Ni-allyl intermediates. Subsequently, the insertion of a second propylene molecule for C-C bond formation can also occur through primary (Ni → C1) or secondary carbon atom (Ni → C2), and then through β-elimination to form the primary dimeric products. Meanwhile, the primary dimers can also isomerize to secondary products. On the more active Ni/Beta-BM10h catalyst, the increase in selectivity to secondary products is attributed to the isomerization of primary dimers on the Ni active species. This is speculated to be also the result of an increasing secondary product concentration with the reaction time (Table 2). Although it is less difficult for the product molecule to desorb from the Ni sites, the primary dimers undergo isomerization quickly. Therefore, the secondary products could be formed in a short space time (Fig. 7). The order of the two insertion modes defines the dimer structure upon the orientation of the adsorbed propylene molecules. The combination of two insertion modes, resulting in different pathways (P1 to P4), determines the distribution of dimer isomers. The obtained reaction result indicates that the main route in dimerization with Ni-based Beta catalysts occurs either by 1,2-insertion (P1) or 2,2-insertion (P3) of propylene because the corresponding dimers were formed preferentially. The choice of carbon atoms is highly related to the steric hindrance of Ni-alkyl intermediate species, causing the dimer distribution to keep away from the thermodynamic equilibrium. Obviously, the second insertion step is more significantly influenced by the steric hindrance of the Ni-alkyl intermediate in the zeolite channel, leading to a much more dominant status for P1 and P3 products. Likewise, by the influence of steric hindrance, the formation of trans isomers was promoted in the ball-milled samples. In all cases, however, the difference in product distribution is not significant, where a certain equilibrium under the four pathways is difficult to break. 4 Conclusions In this study, a highly active Ni/Beta catalyst for propylene dimerization is synthesized by regulating the Ni species coordination environment via mechanochemistry. The as-synthesized Ni/Beta-BM10h exhibits a distinctly higher initial propylene consumption rate of 139.6 molC3=/(molNi·h) at 70 °C than the untreated catalyst and the other ball-milled catalysts. Mechanochemistry provides an additional energy for the interaction between Ni species and the surface hydroxyl groups of the support, forming a larger amount of four-coordinated Ni2+ species coordinating to zeolite framework oxygen atoms. These low-coordinated Ni2+ species are regarded as the active centers for the propylene dimerization. Moreover, the dimerization of propylene on Ni-based Beta catalysts is revealed to follow a Cossee-Arlman type mechanism by in-situ FT-IR. The main dimerization pathway is proposed to occur on the Ni sites via initial π-adsorption of propylene, instead of σ-adsorption, and subsequent two-step insertion through primary or secondary carbon atoms of propylene molecules. The steric hindrance of the Ni-alkyl intermediate is a critical factor for the product selectivity, driving the dimer distribution away from thermodynamic equilibrium and resulting in preferential 1,2-insertion and 2,2-insertion products. This work offers a deeper understanding of propylene dimerization over nickel-based catalysts and provides a feasible strategy for designing efficient catalysts for olefin oligomerization. coredata.dc:description: Propylene oligomerization over nickel-based catalysts has been developed as an attractive route to produce high-value fine chemicals and clean fuels. In this work, the coordination environment of nickel species on high-loading Ni/Beta catalysts is successfully regulated by mechanochemistry, exhibiting a remarkable promotion in activity for propylene dimerization. The optimized ball-milled catalyst with rich four-coordinated nickel species exhibits a higher initial rate of 139.6 molC3=/(molNi·h) than the conventional impregnated catalyst (57.5 molC3=/(molNi·h)). Mechanochemistry induces a strong metal-support interaction by transforming more Ni species into the zeolite channel to generate four-coordinated Ni cations, boosting the adsorption and activation of propylene. Additionally, in-situ Fourier Transform Infrared experiments reveal that propylene dimerization complies with the Cossee-Arlman mechanism via the initial π-adsorption of propylene instead of σ-adsorption. The steric hindrance of the Ni-alkyl intermediate is critical for product selectivity, driving the dimer distribution away from thermodynamic equilibrium and resulting in preferential 1,2-insertion and 2,2-insertion products.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanochemical regulation of the nickel species coordination environment on Ni/Beta catalysts to enhance propylene dimerization
